div.head: Ah&act-We
div.p: have measured Mg self&fusion in spine1 and coexisting melt at bulk chemical equilibrium using an isotopic tracer. The diffusion coefficients were calculated from the measured isotope profiles using a model that includes the complementary diffusion of 24Mg, "Mg, and 26Mg in both phases with the constraint that the Mg content of each phase is constant. This model also permits the calculation of the diffusion coefficient in one phase from the measured data in a coexisting phase. The activation energy and pre-exponential factor for Mg self-diffusion in spine1 are, respectively, 384 f 7 kJ and 74.6 + 1.1 cm'/s. These data indicate Mg diffusion in spine1 is much slower than previous estimates, probably because earlier measurements included grain boundary transport. The activation energy for Mg selfdiffusion in coexisting melt is 343 + 25 kJ and the pre-exponential factor is 7791.9 + 1.3 cm*/s. The results from this study were applied to evaluate cooling rates of Plagioclase-Olivine Inclusions (POI) in the Allende meteorite. Given a maximum melting temperature for POIs of -1 SOO"C, these results show that a 10 pm radius spine1 would equilibrate isotopically with a melt within about 60 min. To preserve Mg isotopic heterogeneity, the POIs must have initially cooled faster than 15 to 250°C/h depending on the initial temperature of flash heating. The cooling rate must also be slow enough to generate the observed basaltic textures. The inferred cooling rate appears to be comparable or up to ten times greater than those inferred from experimental and textural studies of synthetic CA1 systems. The nature of the heating process is thus required to be short with relatively rapid cooling, such as flash heating. However, the relatively rapid cooling cannot be due to radiation into a cold, -400°K nebula but would require radiation into a &her stable hot environment.

div.head: INTRODUCI'ION IN A STUDY OF THE MINERALOGICAL, chemical, and isotopic
div.p: properties of Plagioclase-Olivine Inclusions ( POIs) in the Allende meteorite, SHENG et al. ( 199 1 a) noted that a surprisingly large fraction of the POIs studied were not isotopically homogeneous. Despite textural evidence of a molten or partially molten origin, approximately half of the POIs studied exhibited variations in Mg isotope composition of up to 1 1 '%/ amu between spine1 and coexisting silicates. Based on these observations SHENG et al. ( 199 la) proposed that POIs formed by partial melting of an isotopically heterogeneous aggregate, including some spinels with isotopically fractionated Mg, and silicates with a normal bulk Mg isotope composition. The presence of isotopically heterogeneous spine1 in the POIs requires that the maximum temperature experienced by these objects was low enough and the subsequent cooling rate fast enough to prevent homogenization of Mg isotopes by diffisive transport.

The determination of the thermal history that allows preservation of relict isotopic heterogeneity requires knowledge of the self-diffusion rate of Mg in spinel. Therefore, we designed experiments to determine the self-diffusion coefficients of Mg in single crystal spine1 at temperatures reflecting possible melting conditions of Plagioclase-Olivine Inclusions ( SHENG et al., 199 la). The only available Mg diffusion data in MgAlzO4 are those cited by LINDNER and ARERSTROM ( 1958). They used a radiotracer (**Mg) precipitated on a polycrystalline aggregate of spinels.

A common technique for the preparation of a diffusion couple in simple solids is to coat the diffusing species onto the surface of the sample by electroplating or chemical precipitation (see, e.g., COLES and LONG, 1973;REED and WUENSCH, 1979; CYGAN and LASAGA, 1985). The sample is then annealed to allow species in the thin film to diffuse into the sample. Some of the potential drawbacks to this technique are that the thin film and the crystal are in very different chemical and physical states, and the boundary between them may not be well defined. Imperfections along this contact could serve as a major obstruction to the diffusing species and thus limit the reliability of the data. The thin film method usually does not permit a check on the mass balance of the species transported between the two phases. Another potential problem is that if the thin film has one or more components that are volatile in the enclosing gas, differential volatilization may occur at the surface.

In order to avoid these problems, we designed an experimental approach in which volume diffusion in both phases is maintained. The experiment was defined so that diffusion occurs only in response to an isotopic concentration gradient in media that are each homogeneous with respect to chemical composition. We report on the diffusion coefficients of Mg as a function of temperature in spine1 (MgAl2O4) and coexisting silicate liquids under the condition of bulk chemical equilibrium but bulk isotopic disequilibrium. Our technique permits precise determination of the activation energy and is applicable to many other systems (cf. JUREWICZ and WAT-SON, 1988;WATSON et al., 1985;FREER et al., 1982) in which elements with multiple isotopes (e.g., Mg, Ti, Fe, K, Ca, Si, 0) can be used as tracers. The measured Mg diffusion rates for spine1 are used to establish the temperatures and time scales which control isotopic homogenization of Mg in refractory inclusions found in some meteorites. A preliminary report of this approach has been given by SHENG et al. (199lc).

div.head: EXPERIMENTAL METHOD
div.p: We investigated Mg self-diffusion in MgA1204 (spinel) using isotopic tracers and a diffusion couple. The diffusion couple consists of a single crystal, gem-quality natural spine1 with a normal Mg isotopic composition and spine1 saturated, 25Mgdoped, CaO-MgO-A1,Or-SiO1 melts representative of PO1 compositions. The spine1 crystal was sawed into thin slabs -300 pm thick and one side polished to a smooth, flat surface with I pm diamond paste. The polished spine1 slabs were annealed in air for 24 h at 1500°C. No study of residual defect structures, the effectiveness of the annealing process, or their effect on diffusion was carried out here. "Mgdoped glasses were produced by first mixing *'MgO powder (*'MgO > 98.7%; Oak Ridge National Laboratory) with appropriate amounts of CaCO, , MgO, A120,, and Si02 and then grinding under ethanol in an agate mortar. The mixtures were decarbonated at 800°C for 12 h, followed by melting in Pt crucibles in a Del-Tech VT-3 1 furnace at 1550°C for 24 h in air and quenching in deionized water. Each bulk composition was chosen based on phase equilibria studies ( SHENG et al., 199 I b;SHENG, 1991) to be in equilibrium with spine1 at the desired temperature for the diffusion experiment. Glass chips were analyzed atier melting and verified to be both chemically and isotopically homogeneous by electron probe and ion probe measurements. Magnesium isotope ratios measured in the glasses are consistent with the amount of isotope tracer added into each mixture.

Preparation of the diffusion couple is shown schematically in Fig. 1. Chips of the *'Mg-doped glass were placed in a cylindrical Pt CNcible of 3 mm diameter. The glass chips were remelted inside the crucible to produce a nearly bubble-free glass. Chemical and isotopic compositions of the glass were not changed by the remelting. The The glass was polished after the open end was sawed off. A polished spine1 slab which had been annealed at 1500°C for 24 h was placed against the polished glass. The glass and spine1 slab were fastened together with Pt wire and placed into a furnace at a selected temperature at which the melt-crystal couple was then held for a known time.

remelted glass was then heated to a temperature slightly ( -5°C) below the spine1 saturation temperature of the melt composition to ensure chemical equilibrium with spine]. The melt was then quenched in air to prevent fracturing of the glass. Observation of this re-equilibrated glass under the optical microscope showed that some spine1 grains crystallized from the melt but had settled to the bottom of the crucible. The amount of spine1 crystallized was much less than 5% of the total mass and no significant change in the chemical composition of the melt occurred in the experiments. Measurements of glasses before and after the experiment showed no measured difference in composition. The open end of the crucible was sawed off and the glass polished to a flat surface. The pre-annealed and polished spine1 slab was then placed against the polished surface of the glass and tied together with Pt wire. This couple was then placed into the hot spot of a preheated Del-Tech furnace adjacent to a thermocouple and held at the selected temperature for periods of 0.5 to 20 h. Samples were removed through the top of the furnace and allowed to cool slowly in air, to avoid fracturing spine1 or glass. All experiments were conducted in air at one atmosphere. This procedure produced a welldefined, wetted contact between spine1 and a bubble-free, spine1 saturated melt. Assuming there was no convection in the melt, diffusion coefficients in both melt and crystal can be determined by measurements on the glass (quenched melt) and crystal.

Figure 2a is a backscattered electron image (BSE) ofone run product showing the spine1 slab welded onto the "Mgdoped glass contained within a Pt crucible. As shown in the enlarged BSE image in Fig. 2b, wetting of the melt on the spine1 surface yielded a boundary of spine1 to glass that was a sharp, welded contact. This figure is an illustration of a contact in which the two phases are in chemical equilibrium. In contrast, the spine1 to glass boundary in one experiment, where the melt was over-saturated with respect to spine], shows a serrated contact due to a spine1 growth (Fig. 3), The irregular contact between the two phases indicates that bulk chemical disequilibrium existed at some point during the experiment. The diffusion coefficient of Mg determined from the measured isotope abundance profile in spine1 from this experiment is not consistent with the data from our other experiments and is not included in our discussion.

In some preliminary experiments with a rather limited amount of melt relative to the crystal (T = 1302, 1354, and 1497"C), we found that the 2rrMg/24Mg isotope ratio of the glass measured at the point furthest away from the spinel-glass boundary was significantly lower than the initial ratio oftheglass prior to the experiments. This indicates that the amount of Mg in the melt, and hence the mass of the melt in these experiments, was inadequate to be treated as an infinite medium, complicating any attempt to extract diffusion coefficients for the melt. However, the data for the spine1 in these three experiments could be very well fitted with a diffusion profile (see Results section). In subsequent experiments, we ensured that sufficient glass was present so that the liquid could be treated as an infinite reservoir and verified that the *~M~/*%lp, ratio measured in the glass far from the spine1 following the d&us&r anneal correspondedto that of the initial glass.

At the conclusion of each experiment the diffusion couple was mounted in epoxy and sliced perpendicular to the spinel-glass interface. The resulting surface was polished and carbon coated for chemical and isotopic analysis. The chemical and isotopic compositions of the glasses and spine1 are given in Table 1. The 25Mg/24Mg ratios for each experiment were arbitrary and dependent on the mix of tracer and normal Mg used. If spine1 and melt were in chemical equilibrium for each run, then Mg diffused only in response to the isotopic disequilibrium. That this condition was fulfilled during our experiments was tested by measuring the chemical and isotopic compositions along diffision profiles perpendicular to the interface.

A major concern was the possibility of convection in the melt. To test this possibility chemical and isotopic gradients were measured in the glass across three profiles perpendicular to the spinel-glass interface for experiments at 1495, 14 15, and 1354°C. These three profiles were located at the center of the spinel-glass interface and 1 mm from each side of the center. Points on each profile were measured from close to the interface to 2 mm away from the interface. The melt was found to be chemically uniform. From the absence of differences in isotopic compositions along different profiles at equal distance away from the interface, and the excellent fit to a simple of the profiles enabled us to measure the variations in Mg isotopic composition along a traverse normal to the diffusion interface in both spine1 and glass. Depth profiling techniques required in many isotopic tracer experiments (cf. COLES and LONG, 1973;REED and WUENSCH, 1979;CYGAN and LASAGA, 1985) were not required.

The Mg isotopic compositions in spine1 and glass were determined with the PANURGE ion microprobe following procedures described by HUNEKE et al. ( 1983) andHUTCHEON et al. ( 1987). A massanalyzed, 0.2-0.5 nA i60-primary beam was focussed to a diameter of -5 pm. Secondary Mg+ ions were extracted and accelerated nominally to 4.5 keV. Small (45 V) offsets were applied to the accelerating voltage to compensate for sample charging. An aperture inserted in the sample image plane allowed only positive secondary ions emitted from an 8 pm diameter region concentric with the beam center to enter the mass spectrometer. A mass resolving power of -3000, sufficient to resolve ah molecular interferences in the mass region of interest, and an energy bandpass of -60 V were used in all analyses. Measured isotope ratios were corrected for counting system deadtime (-20 nsec) following the procedure described by HUTCHEON et al. ( 1987). Isotopic profiles were measured by moving the sample under computer control in predetermined increments, while holding the position of the primary beam fixed. In addition to the Mg isotopes, the 28Si+/24Mg+ ratio was recorded to provide a sensitive indicator of the presence of glass. The 2a errors for measured ratios are +3%0 for 2sMg/24Mg and &2% for 26Mg/24Mg.

The data analysis required two types of corrections for instrumental mass-dependent fractionation. Since the 26Mg/24Mg ratio in the "Mgdoped glass was approximately (within *3%) normal, measured 25Mg/24Mg ratios in spine1 and glass were corrected for fractionation using a power law after normalizing to 26Mg/24Mg = 0.13955 (BRIGHAM, 1990). Close to the interface the Mg isotopic compositions in spine1 and glass must approach a common value. The measured isotope ratios in spine1 and glass will, however, differ due to composition-dependent "intrinsic" fractionation. To correct for this fmctionation, an 8k offset was applied to 25Mg/24Mg ratios in glass. The correction was determined from Mg isotope measurements in spine1 and isotopically normal glass. The distances between the sputtered holes from the ion microprobe analyses were determined on a high-precision (resolution -0.5 pm) measuring stage attached to an optical microscope. In calculating the diffusion parameters, we assumed that the measured values, which sample an excitation region with a maximum diameter of 8 pm, represent the value at the center point of the beam. For the profile lengths in this experiment (-50 pm), this assumption introduces negligible errors ( GANGULY et al., diffusion model in both melt and crystal, we inferred that convection was not a factor in our experiments. We also note that bubbles were often present in the original melt that were attached to the capsule. The interior of the melt was always bubble-free. The same bubbles were present during heating for the diffusion period and did not move from their initial position. In addition, no spinels were ever found to be trapped in the melt during this diffusion period.

div.p: Diffusion experiments were performed at seven different temperatures. The results are listed in Table 2. div.p: As can be seen (Fig. 7a), the data exhibit a very good linear relationship on a In D vs. 1 /T plot, suggesting that a single diffusion mechanism governs the transport of Mg in spine1 crystals over the temperature range studied. The activation energy (E) and pm-exponential factor (Do) derived by a linear regression of the experimental diffusion data are, respectively, 384 ? 7 kJ and 74.6 + 1.1 cm*/s. The activation energy for Mg in the melts is deduced from the four experiments in which diffusion data for the melts are available. The activation energy derived from this analysis is 343 + 25 kJ and the preexponential factor is 779 1.9 + 1.3 cm*/s. Although the melts are of different bulk compositions (Table 1 ), the linear relation of the diffusion coefficients derived from an Arrhenius plot (Fig. 7b) suggests that the diffusion coefficient is not a strong function of composition; thus, a constant Dt can be assumed for all PO1 compositions of interest. We also note that the activation energies for Mg diffusion in spine1 and melt are quite similar for the temperature range of our experiments. The pre-exponential factors are, however, very different, thus reflecting the much higher intrinsic jump frequency orjump amplitude in the melt structure as compared with the crystal. The near agreement of the activation energies suggests that the potential barriers for diffusion are the same in both crystal and melt. This is a rather surprising result considering the different phases and the lattice sites that are anticipated for Mg in the melt (octahedral) versus spine1 (tetrahedral ) .

div.head: DISCUS!3ION
div.p: From the characteristics of POIs summarized in the Introduction and discussed in detail by SHENG et al. ( 199 la), it is apparent that the existence of isotopic heterogeneity is the critical clue that provides information on the high-temperature thermal history of these inclusions. Our experiments provide accurate data on the activation energy for Mg diffusion in spine1 and allow us to evaluate the nature of the thermal event(s). The activation energy and pre-exponential factor for Mg diffusion in spine1 extracted from our experi-mental data are somewhat different from those reported by LINDNER and AKERSTR~M ( 1958 ) . Our results give an energy of 384 kJ and a Do of 74.6 cm'/s, compared to their results of 360 kJ and 200 cm'/s, respectively. At the temperature pertinent to melting of POIs, our data yield a Mg diffusion coefficient approximately an order of magnitude smaller than that calculated from the results of LINDNER and AKERSTROM ( 1958). Since their experiments were conducted on a polycrystalline spine1 aggregate, the faster diffusion rate indicated by their data may reflect some combination of grain boundary and volume diffusion, if grain boundary dilfusion is rapid.

The temperature-dependent diffusion coefficient of Mg in spine1 is used to evaluate the duration, thermal limits, and the nature of the heating process that partially melted the POIs. We also discuss the possible initial cooling rates of these partially melted droplets following a heating event.

Since most spine1 grains in POIs are less than 10 pm across and maximum temperatures were on the order of 15OO"C, we would expect an initial cooling rate > 100°C/ h for POIs based on Fig. 9. At 1500°C (the maximum temperature of PO1 melting inferred by SHENG et al., 199 lb), the initial cooling rate for spine1 of 5 pm radius is 356'C/h. At this temperature, the POIs are >95% melted, and the only phases present are spine1 and melt. In some POIs, silicates do not appear until below 1325'C. These POIs are still >80% melted. At this temperature, isotopic homogenization of 5 pm spine1 grains could be avoided if the initial cooling rate was > 15 "C. The nature of the heating process is thus required to be short with relatively rapid cooling, such as flash heating or impact melting. These lower limits on the cooling rates (which depend on grain size) are comparable to or up to ten times greater than those inferred from experimental and textural studies of synthetic CA1 systems (WARK and LOVERING, 1982;MAC-PHERSON et al., 1984;STOLPER and PAQUE, 1986). It thus appears that the igneous textures of POIs are generally compatible with the cooling rates estimated to produce CA1 textures; but much faster rates, which would still preserve isotopic heterogeneity, may be. inconsistent with petrographic observations. Experimental studies of textures of PO1 composition melts as a function of cooling rate will be required to address this case. Faster cooling rates, however, would be compatible with the glassy and skeletal textures of CA chondrules ( BKHOFF and KEIL, 1984 ) . Thus, if isotopically heterogeneous aggregates were also their precursor, and if the melting temperature of some phases did not exceed the liquidus of the bulk aggregate, then Mg isotopic heterogeneity may also be preserved in CA chondrules. The lower limits on cooling rates for POIs are much lower than radiative loss cooling rates of millimeter-size droplets in a cold nebula. This would therefore require formation of POIs in a relatively hot region of the nebula or on a modestly insulated planetary surface after an impact event, possibly in a thin ejecta blanket.

The Mg diffusion data can also be applied to constrain the thermal history of CAIs. For an initial temperature of 142O'C and r. s 2O"C/ h, as suggested for some Type B CAIs ( STOL PER and PAQUE, 1986), our calculations show a characteristic diffusion distance , 199la) this isotopic homogeneity requires either maximum temperatures significantly greater than 1500°C and/or cooling rates much slower than 20°C/ h (the T,,,., / r. ratio must be increased by a factor of at least 5 to 10 over the value given above). Alternatively, Type B CAIs may have formed from isotopically homogeneous precursor material. The presence of Mg isotope heterogeneity in POIs and the results of our diffusion experiments provide one of the most direct means of establishing a constraint on the thermal his-tory of these inclusions. The presence or absence of Mg isotopic heterogeneity is a quantitative measure of the initial flash heating temperature and cooling rate not only of POIs but also of other types of refractory inclusions and chondrules, if we assume that these objects sampled similar material.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: Our Mg diffusion experiments used an isotope exchange technique for phases in chemical equilibrium. This allows precise and simultaneous determination of diffusion coefficients in both phases. For spinel, we obtain an activation energy of 384 + 7 kJ for Mg and pre-exponential coefficient of 74.6 ? 1.1 cm2/s. These values for coexisting melt are calculated to be 343 + 25 kJ and 7791.9 f 1.3 cm2/s, respectively. Since the diffusion coefficients in the coexisting phases are related by common parameters, it is possible to determine the diffusion coefficient of a species in the second phase from the measured data in the first phase and the initial and boundary values. The results suggest that this type of experiment may have broader application and can be applied to other elements (including Si and 0) and other mineral systems. Indeed, simultaneous determination of the diffusion coefficients in a single experiment can readily be done. Such experiments only require the use of labelled isotopes for all of the chemical elements of interest in a single mixture to produce the melt. Using the technique described here, diffusion data in phases where measurement is limited by the slow diffusion rate of a species can be obtained by means of indirect measurement of its transport in a coexisting phase where dilfusion is rapid. We believe that dilli.tsion coefficients on the order of lo-l4 cm'/s can be readily measured by the procedure outlined here. The results from our Mg selfdiffusion experiments in spine1 provide information on the thermal history of POIs. For a maximum melting temperature of POIs of -1500°C the duration of heating at this T is < 1 h and the initial cooling rate at 1500°C is > lOO"C/h. This appears to be faster than the cooling rate of a few tenths to -5O'C/h for CAIs inferred from petrographic studies. For a more reasonable temperature where most of the PO1 is liquid (-135O"C), the cooling rate must be faster than 25'C/ h. We believe this latter value to be the appropriate estimated cooling rate. The melting of POIs probably occurred by flash heating in a hot parcel or region of the nebula. As shown by our previous study ( SHENG et al., 199 la), the absence of 26A1 in most POIs suggests flash heating occurred several million years after CA1 formation. Thus, repetitive heating events may have frequently generated or reprocessed refractory residues which were not themselves primary assemblages but rather material reflecting similar heating processes over a prolonged timescale over very early solar system history. More broadly, we believe that the approach presented here may have widespread application to precise studies of multicomponent diffusion transport and provide insight into transport mechanisms in melts and crystals.
